title: What is panic disorder?
content: Panic disorder is an anxiety disorder where you regularly have sudden attacks of panic or fear. Everyone experiences feelings of anxiety and panic at certain times. It's a natural response to stressful or dangerous situations. But someone with panic disorder has feelings of anxiety, stress and panic regularly and at any time, often for no apparent reason.

title: Symptoms of panic attacks
content: During a panic attack you get a rush of intense mental and physical symptoms. It can come on very quickly and for no apparent reason. Symptoms include a racing heartbeat, feeling faint, sweating, nausea, chest pain, shortness of breath, trembling, hot flushes, chills, shaky limbs, a choking sensation, dizziness, numbness, dry mouth, a feeling of dread or a fear of dying, a churning stomach, tingling in your fingers, and feeling like you're not connected to your body.

title: How long do panic attacks last?
content: Most panic attacks last between 5 and 20 minutes. Some have been reported to last up to an hour. Although panic attacks are frightening, they're not dangerous. An attack will not cause you any physical harm.

title: Cycle of fear
content: You may start to avoid certain situations because you fear they'll trigger another attack. This can create a cycle of living 'in fear of fear.' It can add to your sense of panic and may cause you to have more attacks.

title: What to do during a panic attack
content:
The next time you feel a panic attack coming on:
- Stay where you are, if possible
- Breathe slowly and deeply
- Remind yourself that the attack will pass
- Focus on positive, peaceful and relaxing images
- Remember it's not life threatening

title: Preventing a further attack
content:
It may help to:
- Read a self-help book for anxiety based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
- Try activities like yoga and pilates
- Learn breathing exercises for stress
- Do regular physical exercise
- Avoid sugary food and drinks, caffeine and alcohol, and stop smoking, as they can all make attacks worse

title: Are panic attacks dangerous?
content: Although panic attacks are frightening, they're not dangerous. An attack will not cause you any physical harm, and it's unlikely you'll be admitted to hospital if you have one.

title: Symptoms of a Panic Attack
content: If you experience sudden, intense anxiety and fear, it might be the symptoms of a panic attack. Other symptoms may include: a racing heartbeat, feeling faint, dizzy or lightheaded, a feeling that you're losing control, sweating, trembling or shaking, shortness of breath or breathing very quickly, a tingling in your fingers or lips, feeling sick (nausea). A panic attack usually lasts 5 to 30 minutes. They can be frightening, but they're not dangerous and should not harm you.

title: Things you can try to help with anxiety, fear and panic
content: Do: Try talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, health professional or counsellor. You could also contact Samaritans (call: 116 123 or email: jo@samaritans.org) if you need someone to talk to. Use calming breathing exercises. Exercise – activities such as running, walking, swimming and yoga can help you relax. Find out how to get to sleep if you're struggling. Eat a healthy diet with regular meals to keep your energy levels stable. Consider peer support. Listen to free mental wellbeing audio guides.

title: Things you should avoid
content: Don't: Do not try to do everything at once – set small targets that you can easily achieve. Do not focus on the things you cannot change – focus your time and energy on helping yourself feel better. Do not avoid situations that make you anxious – try slowly building up time spent in worrying situations to gradually reduce anxiety. Try not to tell yourself that you're alone; most people experience anxiety or fear at some point in their life. Try not to use alcohol, cigarettes, gambling or drugs to relieve anxiety as these can all contribute to poor mental health.

title: What helps manage panic attacks
content: Panic attacks can be frightening, but there are things you can do to help yourself cope. It could help to print off these tips, or write them down, and keep them somewhere easy to find. During a panic attack: Focus on your breathing. It can help to concentrate on breathing slowly in and out while counting to five. Stamp on the spot. Some people find this helps control their breathing. Focus on your senses. For example, taste mint-flavoured sweets or gum, or touch or cuddle something soft. Try grounding techniques. They're especially useful if you experience dissociation during panic attacks.

title: After a panic attack: self-care
content: After a panic attack: Think about self-care. It's important to pay attention to what your body needs after you've had a panic attack. For example, you might need to rest somewhere quietly, or eat or drink something. Tell someone you trust. If you feel able to, it could help to let someone know you've had a panic attack. It could be particularly helpful to mention how they might notice if you're having another one, and how you'd like them to help you.

title: Try grounding techniques for panic
content: Grounding techniques can help you feel more connected to the present. They might help you cope with intrusive thoughts or difficult feelings, memories and flashbacks. You could try: Breathing slowly while counting. Tuning into different sounds around you. Walking barefoot and noticing how the ground feels. Wrapping yourself in a blanket and noticing how it feels around your body. Holding an ice cube or splashing cold water on your face. Touching something with an interesting texture or sniffing something with a strong smell. Focus on the sensations you are feeling right now.

title: Overview of Panic Attack and Panic Disorder
content: A panic attack is a sudden episode of intense fear that triggers severe physical reactions when there is no real danger or apparent cause. Panic attacks can be very frightening. When panic attacks occur, you might think you're losing control, having a heart attack or even dying. Many people have just one or two panic attacks in their lifetimes, and the problem goes away when a stressful situation ends. But if you've had recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and spent long periods in constant fear of another attack, you may have a condition called panic disorder. Although panic attacks aren't life-threatening, they can be frightening and significantly affect your quality of life. But treatment can be very effective.

title: Breathing exercise for stress and panic (NHS)
content: This calming breathing technique for stress, anxiety and panic takes just a few minutes and can be done anywhere. Make yourself comfortable, loosen any tight clothes, and either stand, sit, or lie down so you feel supported. Breathe in through your nose and out through your mouth, letting your breath go as deep as is comfortable. Inhale gently, counting from 1 to 5 if you can. Let it flow out gently, counting from 1 to 5 again if helpful. Keep doing this for at least 5 minutes, letting your breath flow deep into your belly without forcing it.

title: 11 Ways to Manage a Panic Attack (MNT)
content: 11 ways to stop a panic attack: 1. Try muscle relaxation: tense a muscle, hold for 5 seconds, say 'relax' as you release, rest for 10 seconds before moving to next muscle. 2. Remember it will pass: accept it's a brief period, symptoms tend to peak within 10 minutes and then subside. 3. Take deep breaths: breathe from the abdomen, slowly for a count of four on inhale and exhale; try 4-7-8 breathing. 4. Find a peaceful spot. 5. Focus on an object. 6. Use the 5-4-3-2-1 grounding technique. 7. Repeat a calming mantra (e.g., 'This too shall pass'). 8. Walk or do light exercise. 9. Take prescribed medication if you have any. 10. Tell someone. 11. Learn your panic triggers.

title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding for panic
content: The 5-4-3-2-1 method: 5 - Look at five separate objects. 4 - Listen for four distinct sounds. 3 - Touch three objects, considering texture and temperature. 2 - Identify two different smells. 1 - Name one thing you can taste. This helps focus the mind and bring awareness back to the present.

title: Remind yourself it will pass
content: During a panic attack, remember these feelings will pass and are not physically harmful. Panic attacks tend to peak within 10 minutes and then symptoms subside. Try acknowledging this is a brief period of concentrated anxiety.

title: Can panic attacks kill you?
content: Panic attacks cannot kill a person. Although the heart rate and breathing increase due to the body's 'fight or flight' response, these symptoms are temporary and not fatal. Even though it feels overwhelming, the body will not sustain lasting harm from a panic attack.

title: Helping someone else during a panic attack
content: If someone else is having a panic attack: help them find a peaceful spot if possible, encourage slow deep breaths, and ask them to focus on a nearby object. Remain calm, stay with them, and remind them that panic attacks always end. Avoid saying 'calm down' or invalidating their fear.
